importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current timeline of the government shutdown and its impact on food stamp benefits.
The day the federal government shutdown began, which directly impacts the timing of food stamp disbursements and funding decisions.
The start date of the government shutdown, which triggered the depletion of food stamp funding and the subsequent actions by the USDA and state agencies.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown period from October 1 to October 18, during which federal funding lapsed and the USDA announced the risk of food stamp program exhaustion in November.
The month of November when food stamp benefits are expected to run out due to lack of federal funding, threatening millions of American families.

keyTakeAways: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing access to food stamps in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has announced that food stamp benefits will run out in two weeks if the funding lapse continues.
The Trump administration has not committed to providing funds to continue SNAP benefits, unlike previous actions taken for other programs.
A contingency fund of $6 billion is available, but it is insufficient to cover the projected $8 billion in November benefits.
17 states have halted new food stamp applications due to the inability to issue partial payments.
The food stamp program is the second major nutrition assistance program at risk, following WIC, which was temporarily protected by a $300 million tariff revenue infusion.
Democrats and state leaders, including New York Governor Kathy Hochul, criticize the administration for prioritizing political agendas over food security.
Food stamp benefits are especially critical around Thanksgiving, with food pantries unable to fill the gap.
Advocacy groups urge the administration to act urgently to prevent vulnerable families from suffering food insecurity.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the official who announced that the food stamp program will run out of money in two weeks and publicly blamed Democrats for political obstruction.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She criticized the Trump administration for halting food stamp benefits, calling it an unprecedented and harmful policy targeting vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal food assistance program (commonly known as food stamps)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a critical safety net for millions of Americans, and its disruption during the shutdown threatens food security for vulnerable populations.

namedEntities.name: WIC
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Nutrition program for pregnant women, new mothers, and young children
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was previously kept afloat during the shutdown using tariff revenue, showing how other nutrition programs are also at risk during funding lapses.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal executive branch under President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is blamed for not providing emergency funding for food stamps and for shifting tariff revenue to WIC, but not to SNAP.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are accused of prioritizing political agendas over food security and are in a dispute with Republicans over spending negotiations.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency responsible for food assistance programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It issued the official warning that SNAP benefits will run dry and directed states to delay payments, acting as the central authority in the program's operation.

namedEntities.name: Governor Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly condemned the administration's decision to halt benefits, emphasizing the need to protect vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: Tami Luhby
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the author of the article, providing the journalistic context and reporting on the crisis.

namedEntities.name: CNN
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the source of the article and platform for public dissemination of the crisis.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A federal government shutdown has placed millions of Americans at risk of losing access to food stamps (SNAP) in November, as the USDA warns that the program will run out of funds within two weeks. The Trump administration has not committed to emergency funding, unlike its earlier actions to support other programs, and has instead relied on tariff revenue to sustain WIC, which is insufficient for SNAP. This has led to 17 states halting new food stamp applications due to payment constraints. Critics, including New York Governor Kathy Hochul and advocacy groups, argue that the administration is prioritizing political agendas over food security, especially during the Thanksgiving season when food access is most critical. The situation highlights the fragility of federal safety net programs during political gridlock.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Next Month Amid Shutdown
